Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43040-01 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
July 2011 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Road Sector Capacity Development 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 4 July 2011) 
Currency Unit –  togrog (MNT) 
MNT1.00 =  $0.0007984 
$1.00 =  MNT1,253.00 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DOR  –  Department of Roads 
  km  –  kilometer 
  MRTCUD  –  Ministry of Road, Transportation, Construction and Urban Development 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UB DOR  –  Capital City (Ulaanbaatar) Department of Roads 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Transport, and information and communication technology (road 
transport, urban transport) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development), governance 
(public administration [national and  decentralized], civil society 
participation), private sector development (policy reforms) 
Location (impact)  –  National (high), urban (medium) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, Government of Japan 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Vice-President-in-Charge, Operations 2 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  T. Duncan, Transport and Communications Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  A. Véron, Transport Economist, EARD 
Team member  S. Lewis-Workman, Transport Economist, EARD 
Peer reviewer  H. Iwasaki, Principal Portfolio Management Specialist, South Asia 
Department 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  After the award of the Oyu Tolgoi copper-gold mining concession in 2009, there are 
prospects for Mongolia’s gross domestic product to triple within 10 years. To proceed on this 
high-growth  track,  Mongolia  will  need  massive  infrastructure  investments.  According  to  its 
National Development Strategy,1 the road sector is expected to implement a large program of 
road sector investments in a short time, and then to manage the new road assets efficiently. As 
a first step toward assisting Mongolia in scaling up the size and quality of its road sector 
activities, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) prepared a sector capacity assessment study.2 At 
the government’s request, ADB subsequently provided small-scale technical assistance (TA)3 to 
support  the  government  and  sector  stakeholders  to  prepare,  in  a  participatory  manner,  a 
National Road Sector Capacity Development Roadmap. 
 
2.  The government has asked ADB for capacity development TA to assist in the initial 
implementation of the road map’s main capacity development activities and planned reforms. 
This report is based on understandings reached with the Government of Mongolia and the 
mission’s observations in the field during the TA fact-finding mission fielded in October 2010. It 
reflects agreements reached on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services for the TA.4 The 
Government of Japan indicated its agreement to finance the TA on 3 May 2011. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Mongolia’s  small  and  low-quality  road  network  is  a  significant  constraint  to  wider 
development and poverty reduction. Most of the roads connecting landlocked Mongolia to its 
neighbors are dirt roads. Many roads in rural areas are in poor condition, frequently impassable, 
and dangerous. Linked to this, Mongolia is experiencing rapid rural–urban migration to the 
capital city, Ulaanbaatar, which provides better economic opportunities. The city’s infrastructure 
has not kept pace with demand. From 1998 to 2008, Ulaanbaatar’s population grew from 
660,000 to 1.05 million and the number of vehicles on the roads increased by 150%. During the 
period, the capacity of the city road network barely expanded, its quality deteriorated, and 
average traffic speed fell by half. 
 
4.  The  government  now  wishes  to  address  the  limitations  in  the  road  sector  in  a 
comprehensive way. Mongolia’s transport sector strategy and priorities are established in the 
national development strategy. The government plans to use mining revenues to expand the 
national paved road network from 2,180 kilometers (km) in 2009 to 5,572 km in 2016, and to 
construct or rehabilitate 500 km of urban roads. This is expected to support mining sector 
development and enable broad-based economic growth. 
 
5.  The  implementation  of  this  investment  program  will,  however,  pose  significant 
challenges. Under the government’s program in the national development strategy, the annual 
physical output of the road industry would need to quadruple in 10 years. There is also a need 
to improve the quality of road construction and maintenance works. The ADB sector capacity 
assessment revealed significant bottlenecks that the government would need to address to 
expand road sector capacity successfully:  
                                                 
1  Great  Hural  of  Mongolia.  2008.  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)-Based  Comprehensive  National 
Development Strategy of Mongolia. Ulaanbaatar. 
2  ADB. 2011. Mongolia: Road Sector Capacity Development to 2016. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Preparing the National Road Sector Capacity Development 
Roadmap. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 July 2011.

2   
(i)  The existing processes, technology, and organization for road construction and 
maintenance  are  suitable  for  small-scale  works  but  not  for  larger-scale 
operations.  
(ii)  The  planning  process  is  not  conducive  to  efficiency.  Necessary  planning 
processes have  frequently  been  bypassed,  and  priorities  have  tended  to  be 
influenced predominantly by political and other non-economic considerations, 
resulting in fragmentation of resources and a low degree of implementation of 
approved plans. 
(iii)  The present level of road maintenance financing covers only 20% of estimated 
needs. In these conditions, only minimal routine maintenance is performed, and 
there is no funding for the periodic maintenance necessary to sustain the service 
quality of the road network in the long term. 
(iv)  The road sector agencies do not have the required implementing powers and 
human capacity to deliver the new construction program efficiently and quickly. 
The  distribution  of  responsibilities  for  works  planning,  procurement,  and 
implementation involves too many different parties. 
(v)  Mongolian contractors have an estimated capacity to undertake 250 km of road 
construction works annually. Unless their capacity is quickly expanded, foreign 
contractors will have to implement the largest share of the road construction 
program, which would limit the benefits to the Mongolian economy. 
(vi)  The  human  resources  of  the  road  sector  are  limited  to  500  engineers  and 
5,000 skilled workers. Twice as many engineers and 40% more workers are 
needed. The skills of many engineers also need to be improved. However, only 
10–20 new road engineers graduate each year, and skilled workers are being 
absorbed by the mining sector.  
 
6.  In the past, ADB and other development partners have advocated improved planning, 
better institutional management, and policy reforms in the road sector. This helped to raise 
awareness  among  sector  stakeholders  about  capacity  development  needs,  but  leadership 
changes hampered progress. A consensus has emerged within the government, interested 
private-sector groups, and development partners that the road sector needs comprehensive 
capacity development and reform, and that this should be approached in an incremental rather 
than  drastic  way.  With  this  understanding,  in  2009  the  government  reestablished  the 
Department of Roads (DOR) as the government agency for road construction and management. 
With ADB support, it convened sector stakeholders working groups5 to prepare the road map.  
 
7.  The road map (Appendix 2) establishes medium- and long-term performance objectives 
for the road sector in terms of the capacity to plan and deliver investment projects, to maintain 
roads in good condition, to develop human resources, and to transfer technology. Under the 
road  map,  the  Ministry  of  Road,  Transportation,  Construction  and  Urban  Development 
(MRTCUD) has adopted the following policy directions: 
 
(i)  Place  responsibility  for policy  implementation  in  the  hands  of  more efficient, 
sufficiently staffed, autonomous, and performance-oriented organizations—the 
DOR for national roads, and the Capital City (Ulaanbaatar) Roads Department 
(UB DOR) for urban roads. 
(ii)  Establish a fair, sufficient, and stable funding source for maintenance by aligning 
user charges with costs attributable to road users and increasing the share that is 
earmarked for maintenance through the Road Fund, with part of the proceeds to 
be used to fund a periodic road maintenance program. 
                                                 
5  Comprising representatives of road agencies, other ministries, road sector professional associations, the chamber 
of commerce, Ulaanbaatar University, and the road construction and consulting industry.

3
(iii)  Increase transparency and stakeholder participation by creating an independent 
body with stakeholder representation (Road Board) to control the use of Road 
Fund proceeds. 
(iv)  Gradually change from carrying out maintenance by force-account to contracted-
out performance-based maintenance. 
(v)  Mandate the use of plan-based priority-setting and decision-making procedures 
in allocating funds. 
(vi)  Increase incentives for contractors to produce quality works, and have stricter 
supervision. 
 
8.  The  government  expects  that  the  implementation  of  these  changes  will  lead  to  a 
smoother  implementation  of  its  infrastructure  investment  plan,  and  better  quality  road 
construction  and  maintenance  works.  This  will  contribute  to  regional  integration,  reduced 
isolation of remote areas, and improved productivity of urban centers. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  of  the  proposed  TA  will  be  improved  road  sector  performance  and 
governance, as measured by indicators including (i) the proportion of projects implemented 
within budget and according to schedule, (ii) the condition of the road network, and (iii) the 
aggregate production capacity of the domestic road industry. The TA will help the government 
implement key policy actions under the road map during 2011–2013. The TA outcome will be 
increased capacity to plan and execute road construction and maintenance. Specifically, the TA 
will  (i)  improve  the  performance  and  governance  of  road  sector  agencies and  institutions; 
(ii) increase the sustainability of the maintenance regime; (iii) enhance road agencies’ planning, 
contract management, and road maintenance capacity; and (iv) support the development of 
road sector education, training, and technical research institutions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.   The  TA  will  have  two  outputs.  Under  the  first  output,  the  TA  will  advise  on  the 
preparation of implementation plans for priority capacity development activities and reforms 
under the road map. Under the second output, the TA will support their implementation and 
build  capacity  in  the  areas  of  institutional  management,  road  maintenance,  contract 
management, investment planning, human resources, and technological development. 
 
11.   Output  1:  Policy  advice  on  road  map  implementation. This output will help the 
government prepare detailed implementation plans in five areas: (i) road agencies’ restructuring 
and  human  resources  development,  (ii)  Road  Board  establishment  and  Road  Fund 
restructuring, (iii) road periodic maintenance program design, (iv) urban road maintenance, and 
(v) road research and technology development. Consulting services will assist the government 
and other sector stakeholders to assess current issues and bottlenecks, identify implementation 
options, and build consensus on preferred implementation options. During this preparatory 
phase,  the  consultants  will  prepare  as  inputs  to  the  discussions:  (i)  a  forward-looking 
assessment of human resource capacity and training needs of DOR and UB DOR, (ii) a road 
user charges review, (iii) a review of DOR’s periodic maintenance plan (prepared with its road 
asset management system) and implementation strategy, (iv) an assessment of urban road 
maintenance needs, and (v) an assessment of applied research and technology transfer needs. 
 
12.   The  implementation  plans  will  include  (i) an  institutional  and  human  resources 
development plan for the DOR and UB DOR; (ii) a proposal for restructuring the Road Fund and

4   
establishing the Road Board, including legal amendments; (iii) an urban road maintenance 
strategy; (iv) a strategy for scaling up education, training, and scientific research programs; and 
(v) a medium-term research program. 
 
13.   Output 2: Capacity building on road map implementation. This component will assist 
the government to (i) reengineer sector institutional arrangements, (ii) introduce sustainable 
maintenance practices, (iii) enhance civil works procurement processes, (iv) enhance transport 
investment planning and project cycle processes, and (v) develop road sector education and 
technical research capacity. The component will combine the following activities: 
(i)  Change management support. The TA consultants will advise sector decision-
makers on the implementation of the road map’s key reforms. They will help 
prepare the operational documents necessary to reengineer sector institutions 
and create new entities planned under the road map. The consultants will also 
provide advice to stakeholders who assume new functions. 
(ii)  Process and systems development. The consultants will help strengthen the 
standards,  manuals,  and  support  systems  in  the  areas  of  (a) periodic 
maintenance management; (b) urban road maintenance; (c) civil works project 
management;  (d)  construction  supervision  and  quality  assurance;  and 
(e) investment planning, project appraisal, and evaluation. 
(iii)  On-the-job  training.  Through  a  combination  of  international  advisors  and 
embedded national consultants, the consultants will provide on-the-job training 
and assistance in the areas of periodic maintenance management, road works 
management and supervision, and transport planning. 
(iv)  Education and formal training. The consultants will prepare a curriculum for 
road engineer retraining. They will develop training modules for road managers, 
engineers,  and  economists;  and  seek  to  establish  partnerships  with  foreign 
educational institutes or professional organizations. Under the TA, a first batch of 
training modules will be delivered, in association with local training providers and 
education institutions to ensure sustainability. 
(v)  Knowledge  products.  The  TA  will  support  sector  scientific  capacity  by 
(a) implementing  small-scale  priority  studies  under  the  medium-term  sector 
research program; and (b) translating into Mongolian and disseminating technical, 
scientific, or educational documents relevant to the road sector. 
(vi)  Public outreach. The consultants will publicize and disseminate the road map, 
e.g., by raising awareness of the changes and reporting on the implementation 
progress to the public, such as via TV, radio, and/or by setting up a website. 
(vii)  Monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  consultants  will  assist  the  road  map 
implementation committee and external stakeholders in monitoring progress on 
road map implementation, on a quarterly basis. At the end of the TA, a capacity 
assessment will be performed to evaluate progress and to agree on a midterm 
updating of the road map. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,300,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB (Appendix 3). The 
government agreed to finance the balance of $300,000 equivalent, including $130,000 in kind 
by  providing  counterpart  staff,  furnished  office  facilities,  and  local  transport  required  for 
implementing the TA, $70,000 for research equipment, and $100,000 for the in-country training 
program.  The  TA  will  also  seek  financial  participation  from  private  companies  for  training 
programs opened to private sector employees.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from September 2011 to September 2013. The executing 
agency  will  be  the  MRTCUD.  A  high-level  steering  committee  will  monitor  the  road  map 
progress, solve major implementation issues, and submit reform proposals to the government. It 
will  be  chaired  by  the  deputy  prime  minister,  include  high-level  representatives  of  the 
Ulaanbaatar  government  and  relevant  ministries,  and  meet  at  least  semiannually.  At  the 
technical  level,  an  implementation  committee  will  guide  and  coordinate  the  road  map 
implementation, facilitate consultants’ access to officials, and discuss issues and decide on 
when to report them to the high-level steering committee. The implementation committee will 
meet  at  least  quarterly.  It  will  be  chaired  by  the  director  general,  DOR,  and  include 
representatives of the MRTCUD, the DOR and UB DOR, the Ministry of Finance and at least 
one  nongovernment  professional  association.  The  DOR  and  UB  DOR  will  have  the 
responsibility  to  prepare  measures  under  the  road  map  and  implement  them,  acting  as 
implementing agencies in their respective areas of responsibility. 
 
16.  The MRTCUD will form a road map coordination unit, under the DOR, to coordinate on a 
day-to-day basis the implementation of the road map and TA, program the TA activities, and 
report activities to the implementation committee and ADB. It will be headed by a high-level 
official and include at least one other professional staff. UB DOR will nominate a TA coordinator 
to  supervise  consultants’  activities,  assist  them  in  undertaking  their  services,  and  provide 
information and data. The stakeholder working groups formed during preparation of the road 
map or subgroups nominated by the DOR will meet regularly to review progress and review the 
outputs  of  the  consultant.  With  the  assistance  of  MRTCUD’s  monitoring  and  evaluation 
department, they will prepare recommendations to the implementation committee. 
 
17.  The TA will require 47 person-months of international and 150 person-months of national 
consulting services to carry out the work defined in the terms of reference (Appendix 4). ADB 
will engage an international consulting firm in association with a national consulting firm using 
the full technical proposal procedure. In selecting this firm, a weight of 90% for quality and 10% 
for cost will be used, reflecting the strategic importance that the government attaches to the 
quality of the TA. To facilitate TA implementation, ADB will also engage an individual national 
project management consultant. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of 
the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement of equipment and software will 
follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
18.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to the Government of Mongolia to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Road Sector Capacity 
Development.

Appendix 3  11 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
($’000)

12  Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Works (Consulting Firm) 
 
1.  Sector Institutional Restructuring 
1.  Strengthen road agencies’ organization and human resources. The main objective of 
this task is to help the Department of Roads (DOR) and the Capital City (Ulaanbaatar) Department 
of Roads (UB DOR) develop the organization, management principles, processes, and human 
capacity  needed  to  meet  their  growing  work  program.  During  the  first  diagnostic  phase,  the 
consultant will seek to answer the following question: What is needed for the DOR and UB DOR to 
implement the government’s medium-term road investment plan and increase maintenance works? 
The consultant’s findings will be compiled into two medium-term institutional development plans, 
including target organization, functions, and main business processes, and internal and external 
reporting and management structures. Human resources development plans will also be prepared. 
Two executive overviews of no more than four pages that can be circulated to the high-level 
steering committee for its endorsement will be prepared.  
 
2.  In the second phase, the consultant will assist in enacting the changes. The main tasks 
under the implementation phase include (i) change management support and just in-time policy 
advice;  (ii)  preparation  of  guidelines  and  procedures;  and  (iii)  operational  support—under  a 
contractual provisional sum, a group of national professionals will be hired on a needs basis during 
implementation  to  assist  the  Ministry  of  Road,  Transportation,  Construction  and  Urban 
Development (MRTCUD), DOR, or UB DOR in strategic areas in which they currently lack capacity, 
e.g., procurement, project preparation and evaluation, and contract management. A list for priority 
areas, objectives, scope of works, and reporting requirements will be submitted by the technical 
assistance (TA) coordinator to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through the consulting firm. The 
DOR and UB DOR, as applicable, will advise the consulting firm on potentially suitable candidates 
(at least three per assignment). 
 
3.  Restructure the Road Fund and reestablish the Road Board. The main objective of this 
task is to assist the MRTCUD and the DOR to restructure the Road Fund with the following two 
objectives: (i) the Road Fund should have sufficient earmarked resources to cover road routine and 
periodic maintenance, and (ii) a Road Board composed of a majority of user representatives 
should control use of Road Fund proceeds. In the first phase, the consultant will propose the 
financial terms and governance mechanisms for Road Fund and Road Board restructuring, as well 
as prepare draft legislation and related regulations. The consultant will prepare an executive 
overview covering the proposed changes of no more than four pages that can be circulated to the 
high-level steering committee for its endorsement. It is expected that the consultant will organize 
necessary  workshops  and  retreats  to  raise  MRTCUD,  DOR,  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance’s 
management awareness. 
  
4.  In the second phase, the consultant will champion and coordinate the development and 
adoption of legislation of a Road Fund and Road Board, establish the Road Board during its initial 
period, prepare manuals for the recommended procedures, and train Road Board members and 
secretariat in the use of systems and procedures. 
 
5.  Monitor  road  map  implementation  and  communicate  with  the  public.  The  main 
objectives of this task are to raise stakeholders’ awareness and help them monitor road map 
implementation. Key tasks include

Appendix 4  13 
(i)  preparing a reporting structure for the road map, and assisting in the preparation of 
quarterly progress reports; 
(ii)  preparing and delivering a public outreach campaign to win public support and 
continue to inform about progress made; 
(iii)  assisting in the preparation of the documentation submitted to the implementation 
committee and higher-level steering committee meetings; and 
(iv)  at the end of the TA, preparing a midterm evaluation of road map implementation, 
identifying key remaining constraints and potential solutions. 
 
2.  Road Maintenance Capacity Building 
6.  Support implementation of a road periodic maintenance program. The consultant’s 
objectives will be to help the DOR implement and evaluate a first paved road periodic maintenance 
program, and help prepare a second year program. Key tasks include but are not limited to  
 
(i)  preparing a work program, including advising on the contracting and supervising 
strategy, and preparing a procurement plan; 
(ii)  monitoring implementation of the program, including through preparing quarterly 
monitoring overviews, identifying bottlenecks, and proposing solutions; 
(iii)  reviewing and improving DOR’s periodic maintenance norms; 
(iv)  preparing specifications and bidding documents; 
(v)  providing  on-the-job  support  to  DOR  staff  in  bid  evaluation  and  contract 
management; 
(vi)  assessing DOR staff contractors’ capacity and works quality; providing training to 
contractors, supervisors, and DOR staff as needed; 
(vii)  evaluating the efficiency of the first year program and recommending improvements 
for the following year; and 
(viii)  assisting the DOR in preparing a second year program. 
 
7.  Define a strategy for Ulaanbaatar city road maintenance. The objectives of this task are 
to help UB DOR prepare a road maintenance strategy and to improve maintenance practices. Key 
tasks during the first phase include 
 
(i)  assessing  the  quality  of  technical  bases  used  for  planning  maintenance  and 
recommending improvements; 
(ii)  assessing  the  operational  efficiency  of  current  road  maintenance  practices  and 
technologies, and recommending improvements; 
(iii)  forecasting routine and periodic maintenance needs; 
(iv)  proposing a contracting framework, e.g., considering the possibility to set up a 
maintenance company in Ulaanbaatar; and 
(v)  preparing a medium-term maintenance strategy. 
 
8.  In  the  second  phase,  the  consultant  will  assist  in  improving  urban  road  maintenance 
practices. Key tasks during this second phase include (i) preparing an urban road maintenance 
standard and manual, and (ii) on-the-job training to urban road maintenance management. 
 
3.  Civil Works Management Capacity Building 
9.  Increase Department of Roads’ project management and procurement capacity. The 
main objective of this task is to increase the DOR’s capacity to manage road construction projects 
and contracts through on-the-job training. The consultant’s highway specialist will act as deputy 
head of the DOR construction unit. Key tasks include but are not limited to

14  Appendix 4 
 
(i)  on-the-job training and support for portfolio management, including works planning, 
portfolio implementation monitoring, and reporting; the consultant will prepare an 
executive report providing an overview of projects, contracts, critical milestones, and 
risks, at least on a quarterly basis; 
(ii)  assessing and advising on implementation and portfolio management strategies and 
processes; 
(iii)  on-the-job training and support to procurement; 
(iv)  on-the-job training and support to project management; 
(v)  regularly evaluating the capacity of procurement and contract management staff and 
the quality of processes followed; and 
(vi)  preparing the concept and terms of reference (TOR) for a project and contract 
management and monitoring system for road projects under the MRTCUD. 
 
10.  Set up an outsourced road supervision system. The main objective of this task is to help 
the DOR outsource and manage road works supervision and foster the use of better quality 
assurance systems by contractors. Key tasks include but are not limited to  
 
(i)  proposing  a  strategy  and  organization  in  the  DOR  to  manage  outsourced 
supervision; 
(ii)  reviewing  and  improving  the  standard  TOR  and  budgets  of  road  supervision 
consultants in use by the DOR; 
(iii)  on-the-job training to DOR staff to contract out and manage supervision consultant 
contracts; 
(iv)  preparing a road supervision manual; 
(v)  assessing  issues  with  contractors’  construction  methods,  work  programs,  and 
quality assurance mechanisms, and recommending quality assurance mechanisms 
to be introduced in Mongolia, as well as improvements to the contractor registration 
and performance management system; and 
(vi)  preparing a quality assurance information leaflet for road construction companies. 
 
4.  Transport Planning Capacity Building 
11.  The objectives of this task are to help the MRTCUD and the DOR improve project planning 
and evaluation capacity, and particularly help update the road master plan. Key tasks include 
 
(i)  reviewing briefly and assessing gaps in current regulatory guidance, practices, and 
staff capacity; 
(ii)  preparing a guideline and provide on-the job training on the elements of a road 
project investment cycle consistent with existing laws; 
(iii)  on  the  basis  of  the  draft  Road  Master  Plan  prepared  in  2007  and  the  road 
maintenance 5-year plan prepared in 2011, providing on-the-job training to the DOR 
to prepare a long-term road master plan for approval, including (a) assessing recent 
and  new  planned  developments,  including  mining  roads;  (b)  assessing  budget 
availability; (c) forecasting traffic; (d) assessing standard costs; (e) recommending 
the  split  between  maintenance,  rehabilitation,  and  investment  spending; 
(f) identifying projects that could be financed by the private sector; and (g) helping 
prioritize corridors based on economic, social, and strategic considerations; and 
(iv)  providing on-the-job training on project appraisal and post-evaluation through the 
analysis of at least four projects.

Appendix 4  15 
5.  Enhancing Training and Research Capacity 
12.  Set up regular training and retraining programs. The objectives of this task are to help 
the DOR set up, deliver, and maintain a regular training and retraining program for road engineers 
and mid-level managers. This should be coherent with the DOR and UB DOR human resources 
development program, but also would target non-DOR staff. Key tasks include but are not limited 
to  
 
(i)  preparing  a  capacity  and  training  needs  assessment  for  the  DOR,  UB  DOR, 
MRTCUD, and state-owned companies; regularly updating the assessment in areas 
of  focus  of  the  TA  to  monitor  progress  through  on-the-job  and  formal  training; 
proposing and fully defining training programs to be delivered on a recurrent basis to 
staff;1 and preparing a training program under the TA; 
(ii)  reviewing current training and retraining programs offered to road engineers and 
managers;  identifying  skill  gaps  and  interests  for  fee-based  engineer  trainings 
among  private  contractors  and  consultants,  based  on  a  survey;  preparing  a 
retraining road engineer program to be delivered regularly; 
(iii)  proposing and assisting in the establishment of an institutional structure for training 
delivery; the consultant will seek to involve road sector professional associations 
and academic entities in training delivery; 
(iv)  preparing or supervising the preparation of complete sets of translated training 
materials,  and  delivering  or  supervising  the  delivery  of  the  training  modules;2 
training should be mainly delivered to Mongolian nationals; and 
(v)  identifying opportunities for and assisting training institutions to obtain funding for 
training,  curricula  improvements,  or  research  from  other  development  partners’ 
programs. 
 
13.  Develop local capacity for road sector technology transfer. The main objective of this 
task is to increase Mongolia’s capacity to transfer and adapt foreign technologies in the road sector. 
In the first phase, the consultant will propose an institutional structure for capacity transfer, and 
define a medium-term road sector technology transfer and research plan. Key tasks include 
 
(i)  assessing current priorities, current local capacity, and issues; 
(ii)  identifying alternatives and recommending an implementation structure, particularly 
analyzing DOR’s proposal to create a road research institute; 
(iii)  consulting with DOR, UB DOR, Ulaanbaatar University, design institutes, and other 
stakeholders on medium-term applied research needs; and 
(iv)  preparing a medium-term road sector technology transfer and research plan. 
 
14.  In  the  second  phase,  the  consultant  will  support  implementation  of  the  recommended 
structure, and organize the delivery of small-scale studies, surveys, and book translation. Key 
tasks include 
 
(i)  preparing  the  institution’s  draft  charter;  business  principles  and  business  plan; 
relationships with government, academia, and the private sector; recommending 
institution staffing needs; 
                                                 
1  The consultant will identify specific needs for improving staff environmental and social safeguards management 
capacity. 
2  In  addition  to  the  engineer  retraining  module,  key  training  may  include  road  maintenance  management,  road 
construction  supervision  and  quality  assurance,  road  works  procurement  and  contract  management,  transport 
planning, and project evaluation.

16  Appendix 4 
 
(ii)  advising  on  the  equipment  needs  for  the  institution  and  assisting  in  their 
procurement (under counterpart financing); 
(iii)  identifying and contacting foreign institutions to organize potential twinning; and 
(iv)  organizing  the  delivery  of  small-scale  studies,  surveys,  and  book  translation—
specifically, under the medium-term road sector technology transfer and research 
plan, the consultant will (a) help prepare the concept and TOR for priority small-
scale research and studies, organize their delivery and control quality; the studies 
will be delivered by local institutes or consultants, hired by the consultant firm, 
potentially using equipment from the university or DOR laboratory; and (b) organize 
the translation of selected books, control quality, and assist in their dissemination. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements and Key Deliverables (Consulting Firm) 
 
15.  The consultant will prepare seven reports on a quarterly basis, including (i) an inception 
report, (ii) an interim report, (iii) a draft final report, (iv) a final report, and (v) three progress reports. 
It is expected that all phase 1 tasks should be essentially complete by the end of the 10th month, 
and that most TA activities, except training and midterm road map evaluation, should be complete 
by the end of the 19th month. 
 
C.  Staffing Requirements (Consulting Firm) 
 
16.  The  core  international  team  will  be  composed  of  (i)  a  team  leader  and  institutional 
development specialist, (ii) a road maintenance specialist, (iii) a transport economist, (iv) a highway 
project and contract management specialist, and (v) a human resources and education specialist. 
The national team will be composed of staff with similar competencies, as well as a public relations 
specialist, and a lawyer (public law and administration). It is expected that the consultant team will 
include one person with a detailed knowledge of road funds management by virtue of having 
worked for it, studied in detail, or advised on the set up of a Road Fund/Road Board. The team 
leader should be full time under the project at least during the first year, and the national deputy 
team leader should be full time during the entire duration of the project. Most inputs will be 
prepared during field time. 
 
D.  Individual Consultant  
 
17.  To facilitate implementation, ADB will hire a national project management consultant. The 
consultant will monitor and help coordinate the TA, and assist in liaising with ADB.

metadata.Title: TAR: Mongolia: Road Sector Capacity Development

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 4 July 2011) 
Currency Unit –  togrog (MNT) 
MNT1.00 =  $0.0007984 
$1.00 =  MNT1,253.00 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DOR  –  Department of Roads 
  km  –  kilometer 
  MRTCUD  –  Ministry of Road, Transportation, Construction and Urban Development 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UB DOR  –  Capital City (Ulaanbaatar) Department of Roads 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Transport, and information and communication technology (road 
transport, urban transport) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development), governance 
(public administration [national and  decentralized], civil society 
participation), private sector development (policy reforms) 
Location (impact)  –  National (high), urban (medium) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, Government of Japan 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Vice-President-in-Charge, Operations 2 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  T. Duncan, Transport and Communications Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  A. Véron, Transport Economist, EARD 
Team member  S. Lewis-Workman, Transport Economist, EARD 
Peer reviewer  H. Iwasaki, Principal Portfolio Management Specialist, South Asia 
Department 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
